column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=XIV .
#Text=Bandits
#Text=When Madeline and her party recovered composure they sat up to watch the finish of the match .
#Text=It came with spectacular suddenness .
#Text=A sharp yell pealed out , and all the cowboys turned attentively in its direction .
#Text=A big black horse had surmounted the rim of the mesa and was just breaking into a run .
#Text=His rider yelled sharply to the cowboys .
#Text=They wheeled to dash toward their grazing horses .
#Text=“ That 's Stewart .
#Text=There is something wrong , ” said Madeline , in alarm .
#Text=Castleton stared .
#Text=The other men exclaimed uneasily .
#Text=The women sought Madeline 's face with anxious eyes .
#Text=The black got into his stride and bore swiftly down upon them .
#Text=“ Oh , look at that horse run ! ” cried Helen .
#Text=“ Look at that fellow ride ! ”

#Text=Helen was not alone in her admiration , for Madeline divided her emotions between growing alarm of some danger menacing and a thrill and quickening of pulse-beat that tingled over her whenever she saw Stewart in violent action .
#Text=No action of his was any longer insignificant , but violent action meant so much .
#Text=It might mean anything .
#Text=For one moment she remembered Stillwell and all his talk about fun , and plots , and tricks to amuse her guest .
#Text=Then she discountenanced the thought .
#Text=Stewart might lend himself to a little fun , but he cared too much for a horse to run him at that speed unless there was imperious need .
#Text=That alone sufficed to answer Madeline 's questioning curiosity .
#Text=And her alarm mounted to fear not so much for herself as for her guests .
#Text=But what danger could there be ?
#Text=She could think of nothing except the guerrillas .

#Text=Whatever threatened , it would be met and checked by this man Stewart , who was thundering up on his fleet horse ; and as he neared her , so that she could see the dark gleam of face and eyes , she had a strange feeling of trust in her dependence upon him .
#Text=The big black was so close to Madeline and her friends that when Stewart pulled him the dust and sand kicked up by his pounding hoofs flew in their faces .
#Text=“ Oh , Stewart , what is it ? ” cried Madeline .
#Text=“ Guess I scared you , Miss Hammond , ” he replied .
#Text=“ But I 'm pressed for time .
#Text=There 's a gang of bandits hiding on the ranch , most likely in a deserted hut .
#Text=They held up a train near Agua Prieta .
#Text=Pat Hawe is with the posse that 's trailing them , and you know Pat has no use for us .
#Text=I 'm afraid it would n't be pleasant for you or your guests to meet either the posse or the bandits . ”
#Text=“ I fancy not , ” said Madeline , considerably relieved .
#Text=“ We 'll hurry back to the house . ”
#Text=They exchanged no more speech at the moment , and Madeline 's guests were silent .
#Text=Perhaps Stewart 's actions and looks belied his calm words .
#Text=His piercing eyes roved round the rim of the mesa , and his face was as hard and stern as chiseled bronze .
#Text=Monty and Nick came galloping up , each leading several horses by the bridles .
#Text=Nels appeared behind them with Majesty , and he was having trouble with the roan .
#Text=Madeline observed that all the other cowboys had disappeared .
#Text=One sharp word from Stewart calmed Madeline 's horse ; the other horses , however , were frightened and not inclined to stand .
#Text=The men mounted without trouble , and likewise Madeline and Florence .
#Text=But Edith Wayne and Mrs. Beck , being nervous and almost helpless , were with difficulty gotten into the saddle .
#Text=“ Beg pardon , but I 'm pressed for time , ” said Stewart , coolly , as with iron arm he forced Dorothy 's horse almost to its knees .
#Text=Dorothy , who was active and plucky , climbed astride ; and when Stewart loosed his hold on bit and mane the horse doubled up and began to buck .
#Text=Dorothy screamed as she shot into the air .
#Text=Stewart , as quick as the horse , leaped forward and caught Dorothy in his arms .
#Text=She had slipped head downward and , had he not caught her , would have had a serious fall .
#Text=Stewart , handling her as if she were a child , turned her right side up to set her upon her feet .
#Text=Dorothy evidently thought only of the spectacle she presented , and made startled motions to readjust her riding-habit .
#Text=It was no time to laugh , though Madeline felt as if she wanted to .
#Text=Besides , it was impossible to be anything but sober with Stewart in violent mood .
#Text=For he had jumped at Dorothy 's stubborn mount .
#Text=All cowboys were masters of horses .
#Text=It was wonderful to see him conquer the vicious animal .
#Text=He was cruel , perhaps , yet it was from necessity .
#Text=When , presently , he led the horse back to Dorothy she mounted without further trouble .
#Text=Meanwhile , Nels and Nick had lifted Helen into her saddle .
#Text=“ We 'll take the side trail , ” said Stewart , shortly , as he swung upon the big black .
#Text=Then he led the way , and the other cowboys trotted in the rear .
#Text=It was only a short distance to the rim of the mesa , and when Madeline saw the steep trail , narrow and choked with weathered stone , she felt that her guests would certainly flinch .
#Text=“ That 's a jolly bad course , ” observed Castleton .
#Text=The women appeared to be speechless .
#Text=Stewart checked his horse at the deep cut where the trail started down .
#Text=“ Boys , drop over , and go slow , ” he said , dismounting .
#Text=“ Flo , you follow .
#Text=Now , ladies , let your horses loose and hold on .
#Text=Lean forward and hang to the pommel .
#Text=It looks bad .
#Text=But the horses are used to such trails . ”
